nodes.bodyText: This 'given' method is not easy to understand. A javadoc on the given method would help avoid having to reverse engineer the code. The name of the method probably ought to describe what kind of dice roll is being returned. EG: givenDiceRollsWithHitSequence, or something like that.

Consider inlining this method, potentially needless indirection. The one liner is more self explanatory than the method name. Seeing givenPlaneUnits(10), it's not clear what the 10 is. The boolean parameter on the create API is needless and we should create an overload on the create method that has a default 'true' on it so the API can then make a lot of sense and be just "create units, count, player".

Side-note, I don't know if this pattern will scale well. Ideally we'd just use a real object here. To do that, extracting the game properties to it's own class and then passing that properties class around would perhaps be the thing to do. To that extent, we could have the battle logic take in that properties object and not a full game data as well for further benefits.
The reason I don't think this will scale is because eventually with more test coverage we'll have re-implemented the full game properties object and have a near duplicate dummy implementation.
There is already an overloaded create method.  But it defaults to false.

The method name explains why exactly one of the planes are hit.  But I can move that to this message as well.
As for the dice rolls, they aren't related to hits.  They are used to randomly select the units that get the hits.
